sense.name: a contrivance, tool, or instrument that has a purpose
sense.commentary: DEVICE[+contrivance][+purposeful][+instrument][+mechanical/+electrical/+chemical] Note: implies a physical artifact of some kind
sense.examples: Computers usually use mice and keyboards as input devices. The man had an explosive device strapped to his body. A life jacket is a basic flotation device. The doctors were able to replace her leg with a prosthetic device.

sense.name: an artistic technique, e.g., literary or theatrical
sense.commentary: DEVICE[+form][+technique][+learned][+artistic][+literary/+theatrical/+graphical] Note: implies a learned, publicly defined and recognized procedure or style
sense.examples: Hyperbole and metonymy are both kinds of rhetorical devices. The actors practiced the device of a stage whisper during their drama class. These ancient painting do not manifest any devices for creating three-dimensional perspective.

sense.name: a plan, maneuver or trick
sense.commentary: DEVICE[+action][+plan][+scheme][+personal][+gimmick/+maneuver] Note: implies a personal, idiosyncratic action (unlike Sense 2)
sense.examples: Mary thinks John's chronic lateness to meetings is a manipulative device to control others. She will resort to any device just to get attention.

sense.name: a decorative or ornamental pattern
sense.examples: Sally chose engraved swans and roses as decorative devices on her wedding invitations. Their family's heraldic shields bear the device of the Flying Falcon.

sense.name: an inclination, nature, tendency
sense.commentary: DEVICE[+state][+nature][+inclination] Note: always in the plural, usually with 'left to one's own'
sense.examples: If left to his own devices, John's son will just sit in front of the television all weekend. The dogs will get into the garbage if left to their own devices.
